Knowledge Point: In addition to its infixability, the autive prefix has the particularity of being (optionally) realized as geminated \forme{-n-} when it occurs before a verb stem or verb prefix in \forme{nɯ\trt}, as in (\ref{ex:nWtCu.kWnA.pjAnnWrga}).

Knowledge Point: First, the autive prefix frequently appears with transitive verbs when the object takes a possessive prefix coreferent with the transitive subject, especially in the case of body parts and other inalienably possessed nouns, to emphasize the fact that the agent is affected by his/her own action. Knowledge Point: The distributed action derivation has a double morphological exponence, combining a prefix \forme{nɤ-} with the partially reduplicated stem of the base verb. Partial reduplication applies to the last syllable of the stem if polysyllabic (§\ref{sec:partial.redp}), and the replicant takes the vowel \forme{-ɯ} by default, except in a few cases studied in §\ref{sec.distributed.action.l} and §\ref{sec.distributed.action.oR}. The distributed action derivation is not compatible with verbs that already have reduplicated forms or a \forme{nɤ-} or \forme{nɯ-} prefix. For instance, \japhug{nɯqambɯmbjom}{fly} lacks a distributed action form; to express this meaning, a serial verb construction (§\ref{sec:svc.manner.other}) with the distributed action derivation \japhug{nɤɕɯɕe}{go around} (from the motion verb \japhug{ɕe}{go}) is used instead, as in (\ref{ex:junWqambWmbjomndZi.junACWCendZi}).

For instance, the meaning of example (\ref{ex:korJWG.nA.YArJWG}) could be expressed with the verb \japhug{nɤrɟɯrɟɯɣ}{run around}.

The base verb \forme{ru} selects a goal in the dative or with locative marking (§\ref{sec:intr.goal}, §\ref{sec:orienting.verbs}), while \forme{rɯru} is transitive (as shown by stem alternation in \ref{ex:paRtshi.YWnWre}) and the entity taken care of by the subject is encoded as object.

Knowledge Point: The rare verb \japhug{rnde}{get into trouble} is only attested in the expression in (\ref{ex:pWrndeta}). The \forme{-t-} suffix shows that this verb is morphologically transitive (§\ref{sec:transitivity.morphology}), despite being unable to take an overt object.
Content 1: \gll kɤ-rndu sɤznɤ pɯ-rnde-t-a | \gls INF-obtain COMIT AOR-get.into.trouble-PST:TR-1SG | \glt `I not only did not obtain anything, but in addition I got into trouble.'

Knowledge Point: The co-occurrence of \forme{rnde} with \japhug{rndu}{obtain} in the expression exemplified by (\ref{ex:pWrndeta}) is probably not only a matter of euphony, but also of morphological relationship (a figura etymologica). The verb \forme{rnde} is invariable, but its stem is identical to the stem III (§\ref{sec:stem3.form}) of \forme{rndu} as in (\ref{ex:kro.Zo.YWrnde}).

Content 2: \gll ɯʑo stɯsti ʑo tu-ɕe qʰe, tɕe kʰro ʑo ɲɯ-rnde kʰi. | \gls 3SG alone EMPH IPFV:UP-go LNK LNK a.lot EMPH SENS-obtain[III] HEARSAY | \glt `She goes [up there in the mountain], and found a lot of mushrooms (they say).'

Knowledge Point: In the case of \forme{rnde} however, the fact that this rare verb is mainly attested in Aorist forms, where a Stem III is not possible makes the backformation hypothesis less likely. In addition, although the meaning of \japhug{rnde}{get into trouble} is relatable to that of \japhug{rndu}{obtain} (`obtain/get problems/trouble'), it is not a simple narrowing of the meaning of \forme{rndu}, a verb all of whose attestations refer to positive events (see \ref{ex:kro.Zo.YWrnde} above, as well as \ref{ex:CpWrndutCi} in §\ref{sec:AM.volitionality}).\footnote{For the backformation hypothesis to work, one would need to suppose that at an earlier stage, \japhug{rndu}{obtain} with a non-overt object had a negative overtone `get/obtain it' \fl{} `get into trouble'. }
